title: 103_s1654
content: The Northern Cheyenne Indian Reserved Water Rights Settlement Act of 1992. Environmental Costs: The Northern Cheyenne Indian Reserved Water Rights Settlement Act of 1992 is amended to include new subsections (f) and (g) regarding the Tongue River Dam Project. The United States is solely responsible for all environmental compliance costs and fish and wildlife mitigation measures related to the project. Up to $625,000 can be used for fish and wildlife mitigation costs associated with Tongue River Dam construction. The Tongue River Dam Project under the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reserved Water Rights Settlement Act of 1992 includes provisions for wildlife mitigation costs and environmental compliance activities. Montana will be reimbursed for approved expenditures related to the project. The Act authorizes funds for these purposes. The authorization of appropriations in the Act will only be effective after approval by the Montana water court. The amendments made by this section are retroactively effective as of September 30, 1992. The San Carlos Apache Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act of 1992 is amended to change "reimbursable" to "nonreimbursable". The amendment is retroactively effective from October 30, 1992. Additionally, there is a section on tribally controlled community colleges. SEC. 3 amends the Department of the Interior Appropriations Act of 1994 regarding tribally controlled community colleges. It replaces a section of the Higher Education Act with a new reference. SEC. 4 pertains to the White Earth Reservation Land Settlement Act of 1985. Section 7 of the White Earth Reservation Land Settlement Act of 1985 is amended to authorize the Secretary to make a one-time deletion from certain lists of allotments or interests that do not meet specific criteria. The Secretary must publish notices of deletions in the Federal Register, and determinations for deletions can be judicially reviewed. Judicial review of allotments or interests under the White Earth Reservation Land Settlement Act of 1985 can be done within 90 days of notice in the Federal Register. Legal action must be filed within this period, with exclusive jurisdiction in the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota. SEC. 5 of the Act is amended to change the reservation area for the Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Community of Oregon. The curr_chunk provides details about land parcels and their sizes, with a total value of $9,879.65. The curr_chunk discusses the privileges and immunities of Indian tribes, prohibiting new regulations that classify, enhance, or diminish these privileges. It also addresses existing regulations of departments or agencies of the United States. The curr_chunk prohibits new regulations that affect the privileges and immunities of federally recognized Indian tribes relative to other tribes. The curr_chunk mentions the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States, who also serves as the President of the Senate.
